description: The StartPosition event type, a subclass of PersonnelEvent, refers to the commencement of a new role or position by an individual or group. Example triggers include 'becoming', 'return', 'replace', 'head', and 'was'.

This event type captures the initiation of a professional or official role, often marked by a change in title, responsibilities, or location. Key characteristics include the presence of a person or entity starting a new position and the context of the role.

Unlike the EndPosition event type, which signifies the conclusion of a role, the StartPosition event focuses on the beginning of a new role. For instance, 'former' is indicative of EndPosition, not StartPosition.
Triggers such as 'appointed', 'elected', and 'promoted' are also indicative of the StartPosition event type, highlighting the formal commencement of a new role or position.
The outcomes of this event type include the establishment of a new professional or official status for the person or entity involved, often accompanied by a change in duties or location.

attributes.mention: The text span that triggers the event.
time: The 'time' argument specifies when the person or entity started the new position. It is crucial for understanding the temporal context of the event. Example: 'since early 2001'.
This argument helps to place the event within a specific timeframe, providing clarity on the duration or exact start date of the new role. Example: 'from 1989 to 1998'.
In cases where the exact time is not mentioned, relative time expressions like 'recently' or 'last month' can be used. Example: 'recently appointed'.
The 'time' argument can also include historical periods or specific dates, enhancing the precision of the event annotation. Example: 'in 1999'.
Edge cases include ambiguous time references which should be clarified through context or additional information. Example: 'early this year'.
entity: The 'entity' argument refers to the organization, company, or group associated with the new position. It provides context on the affiliation of the person or entity. Example: 'U.N.'.
This argument is important for identifying the institutional or organizational context of the new role. Example: 'United Nations'.
In some cases, the entity may be implied rather than explicitly stated, requiring inference from the surrounding text. Example: 'administration'.
The 'entity' argument can also include specific units or departments within larger organizations. Example: 'US unit'.
Edge cases include generic references to entities which should be specified if possible. Example: 'media group'.
position: The 'position' argument specifies the title or role that the person or entity is starting. It is essential for understanding the nature of the new position. Example: 'chief executive'.
This argument helps to clarify the responsibilities and status associated with the new role. Example: 'diplomat'.
In some cases, the position may be described in terms of duties rather than a formal title. Example: 'head the U.S.-led interim administration'.
The 'position' argument can also include hierarchical or rank-related information. Example: 'chairman'.
Edge cases include vague or informal descriptions of positions which should be clarified through context. Example: 'representative'.
place: The 'place' argument indicates the location where the new position is being started. It provides geographical context for the event. Example: 'Geneva'.
This argument is important for understanding the spatial context of the new role. Example: 'Paris'.
In some cases, the place may be described in terms of broader regions or specific sites within a city. Example: 'headquarters'.
The 'place' argument can also include historical or culturally significant locations. Example: '4,000-year-old ziggurat at Ur'.
Edge cases include ambiguous or multiple locations which should be specified if possible. Example: 'United Nations'.
person: The 'person' argument refers to the individual or group starting the new position. It is crucial for identifying the main actor in the event. Example: 'Al-Douri'.
This argument helps to specify who is involved in the commencement of the new role. Example: 'Jean-Rene Fourtou'.
In some cases, the person may be described in terms of their previous roles or affiliations. Example: 'Retired Lt. Gen. Jay Garner'.
The 'person' argument can also include groups or collectives starting new positions. Example: 'Ba'athists, officers, Republican Guards, Mukhabarat, personnel'.
Edge cases include unnamed or generic references to persons which should be specified if possible. Example: 'He'.
